t: Judges 5
The Song of Deborah and Barak
Then*p sang Deborah and Barak the son of Abinoam on that day:
“That*pn the leaders took the lead in Israel, that*ld the people offered themselves willingly, bless*ld the Lord!*s
“Hear,*pn O kings; give ear, O princes; to*ld the Lord*s I will sing; I*ld will make melody to the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
“Lord,*spn when you went out from Seir, when*ld you marched from the region of Edom, the*ln earth trembled and*ld the heavens dropped, yes,*ld the clouds dropped water.
The*ln mountains quaked before the Lord,*s even*ld Sinai before the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
“In*pn the days of Shamgar, son of Anath, in*ld the days of Jael, the highways were abandoned, and*ld travelers kept to the byways.
The*ln villagers ceased in Israel; they*ld ceased to be until I arose; I,*ld Deborah, arose as a mother in Israel.
When*ln new gods were chosen, then*ld war was in the gates. Was*ln shield or spear to be seen among*ld forty thousand in Israel?
My*ln heart goes out to the commanders of Israel who*ld offered themselves willingly among the people. Bless*ld the Lord.*s
“Tell*pn of it, you who ride on white donkeys, you*ld who sit on rich carpets and*ld you who walk by the way.

To*ln the sound of musicians at the watering places, there*ld they repeat the righteous triumphs of the Lord,*s the*ld righteous triumphs of his villagers in Israel. “Then*pn down to the gates marched the people of the Lord.*s
“Awake,*pn awake, Deborah! Awake,*ld awake, break out in a song! Arise,*ln Barak, lead away your captives, O*ld son of Abinoam.
Then*ln down marched the remnant of the noble; the*ld people of the Lord*s marched down for me against the mighty.

From*ln Ephraim their root they marched down into the valley, following*ld you, Benjamin, with your kinsmen; from*ln Machir marched down the commanders, and*ld from Zebulun those who bear the lieutenant’s staff;
the*ln princes of Issachar came with Deborah, and*ld Issachar faithful to Barak; into*ld the valley they rushed at his heels. Among*ln the clans of Reuben there*ld were great searchings of heart.
Why*ln did you sit still among the sheepfolds, to*ld hear the whistling for the flocks? Among*ln the clans of Reuben there*ld were great searchings of heart.
Gilead*ln stayed beyond the Jordan; and*ld Dan, why did he stay with the ships? Asher*ln sat still at the coast of the sea, staying*ld by his landings.
Zebulun*ln is a people who risked their lives to the death; Naphtali,*ld too, on the heights of the field.
“The*pn kings came, they fought; then*ld fought the kings of Canaan, at*ln Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo; they*ld got no spoils of silver.
From*ln heaven the stars fought, from*ld their courses they fought against Sisera.
The*ln torrent Kishon swept them away, the*ld ancient torrent, the torrent Kishon. March*ld on, my soul, with might!
“Then*pn loud beat the horses’ hoofs with*ld the galloping, galloping of his steeds.
“Curse*pn Meroz, says the angel of the Lord,*s curse*ld its inhabitants thoroughly, because*ln they did not come to the help of the Lord,*s to*ld the help of the Lord*s against the mighty.
“Most*pn blessed of women be Jael, the*ld wife of Heber the Kenite, of*ld tent-dwelling women most blessed.
He*ln asked for water and she gave him milk; she*ld brought him curds in a noble’s bowl.
She*ln sent her hand to the tent peg and*ld her right hand to the workmen’s mallet; she*ln struck Sisera; she*ld crushed his head; she*ld shattered and pierced his temple.
Between*ln her feet he*ld sank, he fell, he lay still; between*ln her feet he*ld sank, he fell; where*ln he sank, there*ld he fell— dead.
“Out*pn of the window she peered, the*ld mother of Sisera wailed through the lattice: ‘Why*ln is his chariot so long in coming? Why*ld tarry the hoofbeats of his chariots?’
Her*ln wisest princesses answer, indeed,*ld she answers herself,

‘Have*ln they not found and divided the spoil?— A*ld womb or two for every man; spoil*ln of dyed materials for Sisera, spoil*ld of dyed materials embroidered, two*ld pieces of dyed work embroidered for the neck as spoil?’
“So*pn may all your enemies perish, O Lord!*s But*ld your friends be like the sun as he rises in his might.” And*p the land had rest for forty years.
